title: NBA midseason grades: Report cards for every West team, plus each roster's MVP so far
description: Which West teams deserve the highest marks at the regular season's midway point? Which team gets an F?
content_html: Every NBA team in the Western Conference has played 41 games and most have played more, which means we are due for a midseason report card. (Check out our East report card and midseason awards, too.)The Oklahoma City Thunder (37-8) went 6-6 over a three-week stretch during the holidays and still hold a commanding lead on the conferenceâ€™s No. 1 seed. That stretch, though, included four losses to would-be challengers, leaving open the possibility they arenâ€™t such a clear-cut favorite.[Subscribe to Yahoo Sports NBA on YouTube]The Denver Nuggets (29-15), who are surviving a spell without Nikola JokiÄ‡, the worldâ€™s best player, look every bit the contender when healthy. The San Antonio Spurs (30-14) handed OKC three of those losses, making clear that they could compete in a seven-game series with the defending champions. The Minnesota Timberwolves (27-17) also recently upset the Thunder.Each of those four teams, all serious contenders, warrants an A. The West also boasts the one F from our midseason report card, but before we give away too much, let us get to the grades.Dallas Mavericks â€¢ Denver Nuggets â€¢ Golden State Warriors â€¢ Houston Rockets â€¢ Los Angeles Clippers â€¢ Los Angeles Lakers â€¢ Memphis Grizzlies â€¢ Minnesota Timberwolves â€¢ New Orleans Pelicans â€¢ Oklahoma City Thunder â€¢ Phoenix Suns â€¢ Portland Trail Blazers â€¢ Sacramento Kings â€¢ San Antonio Spurs â€¢ Utah Jazz(First-quarter grades can be found here.)(Mallory Bielecki/Yahoo Sports Illustration)Dallas Mavericks (18-26)Midseason MVP: Cooper Flagg (19-6-4 on 48/29/81)Offensive rating: 110.4 (27th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 112.6 (7th)Best lineup: Flagg â€¢ Ryan Nembhard â€¢ Naji Marshall â€¢ P.J. Washington â€¢ Anthony Davis (+29 in 47 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 9-15 â€¢ Against losing teams: 9-11Comments: Anthony Davis is one of the few true game-changing forces in the NBA, only he cannot stay healthy, and he turns 33 years old in March. â€¦ This time, it is a hand injury that will keep him out through the All-Star break. â€¦ Shop him? For what? â€¦ The alternative: Keep him, get Kyrie Irving healthy, and see what you have with them and Cooper Flagg(!) next season. â€¦ What is the point of chasing a play-in bid? May as well add another high pick to their mix.Grade: DDenver Nuggets (29-15)Midseason MVP: Nikola JokiÄ‡ (30-12-11 on 61/44/85)Offensive rating: 121.5 (1st) â€¢ Defensive rating: 117.0 (24th)Best lineup: JokiÄ‡ â€¢ Jamal Murray â€¢ Christian Braun â€¢ Cam Johnson â€¢ Aaron Gordon (+42 in 159 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 13-8 â€¢ Against losing teams: 16-7Comments: Nikola JokiÄ‡ leads the NBA in assists and rebounds per game and true shooting percentage. Needless to say, nobody has done that. â€¦ He is nursing a knee injury, and Denver (somehow) is 7-5 in his absence, holding on to the No. 3 seed in the West. â€¦ It speaks to the teamâ€™s depth this season. â€¦ The emergence of Peyton Watson (22-6-3 on 50/42/71) over those last 12 games is beyond helpful. â€¦ When healthy, this is as true of a contender as there is in the league.Â Grade: AGolden State Warriors (25-20)Midseason MVP: Stephen Curry (27-4-5 on 47/39/93)Offensive rating: 115.8 (12th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 112.8 (9th)Best lineup: Curry â€¢ Brandin Podziemski â€¢ Jimmy Butler â€¢ Jonathan Kuminga â€¢ Draymond Green (+25 in 65 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 11-15 â€¢ Against losing teams: 14-5Comments: Man, news of Jimmy Butlerâ€™s torn ACL is a bummer. â€¦ The framework of these Warriors, knocking on the door of the top-10 on both offense and defense, was a good one. â€¦ Stephen Curry is a shooting machine. This is not normal for a 37-year-old. â€¦ Yet, Golden State has been outscored by 2.7 points per 100 possessions when Butler is not on the court. â€¦ The dynasty, for all intents and purposes, is completely cooked, if it wasnâ€™t already. â€¦ This is sad.Grade: CHouston Rockets (26-15)Midseason MVP: Kevin Durant (26-5-5 on 51/40/89)Offensive rating: 118.9 (3rd) â€¢ Defensive rating: 112.4 (5th)Best lineup: Durant â€¢ Amen Thompson â€¢ Josh Okogie â€¢ Jabari Smith Jr. â€¢ Alperen ÅengÃ¼n (+36 in 276 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 14-8 â€¢ Against losing teams: 12-7Comments: Without the injured Fred VanVleet, the Rockets lack an organizer of a point guard, and they have done quite well to survive it, posting the NBAâ€™s third-rated offense. â€¦ Still, there are times in the clutch, where the Rockets are 10-12, when it is clear they need one. â€¦ It helps to have Kevin Durant, one of historyâ€™s most lethal isolation scorers â€”Â still, at 37 years old. Not normal, either, by the way. â€¦ It would be nice if coach Ime Udoka trusted Reed Sheppard more.Grade: BLos Angeles Clippers (19-24)Midseason MVP: Kawhi Leonard (28-6-4 on 50/40/94)Offensive rating: 115.5 (13th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 116.8 (22nd)Best lineup: Leonard â€¢ James Harden â€¢ Kris Dunn â€¢ John Collins â€¢ Ivica Zubac (+10 in 250 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 9-17 â€¢ Against losing teams: 10-7Comments: The Clippers earned an F on our first-quarter report card and deserved it. â€¦ Since then, they are 13-8, outscoring opponents by 2.7 points per 100 possessions â€” something like a playoff team. â€¦ Only their terrible start has left them clutching to a play-in tournament berth. â€¦ It is incumbent upon the Clippers to make the playoffs, if only so they do not hand their lottery pick to the Thunder. â€¦ Kawhi Leonardâ€™s knee is acting up again. â€¦ The team is, plainly, too old.Grade: DLos Angeles Lakers (26-16)Midseason MVP: Luka DonÄiÄ‡ (34-8-9 on 47/34/79)Offensive rating: 116.9 (8th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 117.3 (25th)Best lineup: DonÄiÄ‡ â€¢ Austin Reaves â€¢ Marcus Smart â€¢ Rui Hachimura â€¢ Deandre Ayton (+31 in 81 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 10-11 â€¢ Against losing teams: 16-5Comments: The Lakers are 13-1 in the clutch, because they have Luka DonÄiÄ‡, LeBron James and Austin Reaves, an incredible offensive trio, who know how to close games. â€¦ This is how they are in fifth place, in line to make the playoffs, despite a negative point differential. â€¦ When James, DonÄiÄ‡ and Reaves share the floor, the Lakers allow 118.7 points per 100 possessions, the equivalent of a bottom-five defense. â€¦ This is, to be clear, a fatal flaw. JJ Redick knows this.Grade: BMemphis Grizzlies (18-24)Midseason MVP: Jaren Jackson Jr. (19-6-2 on 48/37/77)Offensive rating: 112.9 (23rd) â€¢ Defensive rating: 114.0 (14th)Best lineup: Jackson â€¢ Vince Williams â€¢ Cedric Coward â€¢ Jaylen Wells â€¢ Zach Edey (+27 in 102 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 5-20 â€¢ Against losing teams: 13-4Comments: In two games since returning to Memphisâ€™ lineup, Ja Morant has totaled 47 points and 25 assists. â€¦ It feels like an audition for the rest of the league. â€¦ After all, the Grizzlies are reportedly listening to offers for Morant, and he seems ready to move on from Memphis, too. â€¦ The market is tepid. For now. â€¦ Too bad Zach Edey cannot stay on the court. It is actually intriguing how good the Grizzlies can be at full force. â€¦ But it is always something with Morant.Grade: DMinnesota Timberwolves (27-17)Midseason MVP: Anthony Edwards (30-5-4 on 50/41/79)Offensive rating: 117.5 (6th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 112.9 (10th)Best lineup: Edwards â€¢Â Donte DiVincenzo â€¢ Jaden McDaniels â€¢ Julius Randle â€¢ Rudy Gobert (+85 in 424 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 10-12 â€¢ Against losing teams: 17-5Comments: The goal of these Timberwolves was to reestablish themselves as the team that has reached consecutive conference finals â€”Â with a chance to get further â€” and they have done that, even beating the Thunder in one of their two matchups. â€¦ Did the Wolves win their trade of Karl-Anthony Towns? Julius Randle has been just as good, if not better, and Donte DiVincenzo is a nice added bonus. â€¦ Anthony Edwards deserved a start in the All-Star Game.Grade: ANew Orleans Pelicans (10-36)Midseason MVP: Trey Murphy III (22-6-4 on 49/38/90)Offensive rating: 111.9 (25th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 119.0 (27th)Best lineup: Murphy â€¢ Jeremiah Fears â€¢ Herbert Jones â€¢ Saddiq Bey â€¢ Derik Queen (+15 in 113 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 2-27 â€¢ Against losing teams: 8-9Comments: Rookie Derik Queen is good, averaging a 13-7-4 on almost 50% shooting. â€¦ That still does not excuse the Pelicansâ€™ decision to trade their unprotected 2026 first-round pick for him. That selection, belonging to Atlanta, is one of the single-best assets in the NBA. â€¦ Zion Williamson has played 20 straight games and still New Orleans stinks. â€¦ Might the Pelicans finally trade him? â€¦ Trey Murphy is the real prize. Just about every NBA team could use him.Grade: FOklahoma City Thunder (37-8)Midseason MVP: Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (32-4-6 on 56/40/89)Offensive rating: 118.5 (5th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 105.2 (1st)Best lineup: Gilgeous-Alexander â€¢ Cason Wallace â€¢ Lu Dort â€¢ Jalen Williams â€¢ Chet Holmgren (+69 in 117 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 16-7 â€¢ Against losing teams: 21-1Comments: The Thunder, still the favorites, no longer seem invulnerable. For almost a month, they played .500 basketball. â€¦ Still they lead the West by 6.5 games. Still they are on a 68-win pace. â€¦ Since then, they are 7-1, losing only by two to the Heat in Miami, reestablishing the defending champions as the team to beat. â€¦ Shai Gilgeous-Alexander is on pace to become the first player to average 30 points in four straight seasons since Michael Jordan.Grade: APhoenix Suns (27-17)Midseason MVP: Devin Booker (25-4-6 on 45/30/86)Offensive rating: 114.9 (14th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 112.2 (4th)Best lineup: Booker â€¢ Collin Gillespie â€¢ Dillon Brooks â€¢ Royce Oâ€™Neale â€¢ Mark Williams (+48 in 231 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 12-13 â€¢ Against losing teams: 15-4Comments: Nobody figured these Suns for a guaranteed playoff spot in the crowded Western Conference, but there they stand through the seasonâ€™s first half. â€¦ The effort of Dillon Brooks, their surprising culture-setter, is contagious. â€¦ Jalen Green is finally back, and he looked pretty good in his return. â€¦ How well he fits their newfound culture is a question. â€¦ The Suns have played well enough to warrant an upgrade at the deadline, though they have few picks to trade.Grade: APortland Trail Blazers (22-22)Midseason MVP: Deni Avdija (26-7-7 on 47/36/80)Offensive rating: 113.5 (21st) â€¢ Defensive rating: 115.4 (17th)Best lineup: Avdija â€¢Â Shaedon Sharpe â€¢ Kris Murray â€¢ Toumani Camara â€¢ Donovan Clingan (+15 in 106 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 12-16 â€¢ Against losing teams: 10-6Comments: Deni Avdija should be an All-Star if we are basing our selections on how well they have played this season. â€¦ It is a good thing, too, because none of their recent first-round picks has established himself as a star. â€¦ There are a lot of players to like, though, including Caleb Love, who is averaging a 16-3-3 on 45/39/71 shooting splits in his last 15 appearances. â€¦ What does more of the same get them? More middling. It is painful to be stuck in the NBAâ€™s middle.Grade: CSacramento Kings (12-33)Midseason MVP: DeMar DeRozan (19-3-4 on 51/36/87)Offensive rating: 109.4 (29th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 119.1 (28th)Best lineup: DeRozan â€¢Â Russell Westbrook â€¢ Zach LaVine â€¢ Keegan Murray â€¢ Maxime Raynaud (+14 in 90 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 8-24 â€¢ Against losing teams: 4-9Comments: What to say about these Kings. Did they really think the combination of DeMar DeRozan, Zach LaVine and Russell Westbrook would bear fruit? â€¦ At least Domantas Sabonis is back from a knee injury, though he has yet to make a start in his return. â€¦ Everybody on the team is available in a trade. â€¦ What young player would you want from this roster? Maybe Keegan Murray or Maxime Raynaud? â€¦ Their saving grace: They own their first-round pick.Grade: DSan Antonio Spurs (30-14)Midseason MVP: Victor Wembanyama (24-11-3 on 51/38/84)Offensive rating: 116.6 (9th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 111.6 (3rd)Best lineup: Wembanyama â€¢ Deâ€™Aaron Fox â€¢Â Stephon Castle â€¢ Julian Champagnie â€¢ Harrison Barnes (+42 in 84 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 14-12 â€¢ Against losing teams: 16-2Comments: Victor Wembanyama is a walking top-flight defense at 22 years old. The Spurs own the equivalent of the NBAâ€™s best defense (104.5 points allowed per 100 possessions) when he is on the court, and they operate like the leagueâ€™s 14th-rated outfit when he is on the bench. (Still not bad, by the way.) â€¦ Stephon Castle has made a leap. Dylan Harper appears ready to make one. â€¦ San Antonio is waaaaaaaay ahead of schedule on the quest to build its next contender.Grade: AUtah Jazz (15-29)Midseason MVP: Keyonte George (24-4-7 on 46/38/90)Offensive rating: 114.4 (17th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 122.2 (30th)Best lineup: George â€¢ Brice Sensabaugh â€¢ Svi Mykhailiuk â€¢ Lauri Markkanen â€¢ Jusuf Nurkic (+2 in 47 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 7-20 â€¢ Against losing teams: 8-9Comments: The emergence of Keyonte George is a franchise-altering development. â€¦ Whereas once it made sense to trade Lauri Markkanen, now there is at least reason to believe the two of them could form the basis of a competitive team. â€¦ Their defensive rating is somehow worse than the leagueâ€™s best offensive rating. â€¦ It would be nice if Markkanen played. â€¦ But their mission is clear, since the Jazz owe a top-eight protected pick to OKC.Grade: C
author: Ben Rohrbach

title: Zion? Anthony Davis? Stand pat? 3 paths forward for Steph Curry's Warriors
description: The Warriors have a tough decision ahead of them in the aftermath of Jimmy Butler's injury.
content_html: As soon as Jimmy Butler crumbled to the floor against the Miami Heat on Monday, Warriors center Quinten Post knew it wasnâ€™t good. Butler screeched in pain holding his right knee, while Post, just a few inches away, stood in fear grabbing the back of his head with both hands.Â When Butler went down, so too did the Warriorsâ€™ chances of making a deep run this season. Thatâ€™s the cruel thing about it all. The Warriors had emerged as a legitimate West threat. With a three-point lead at the time of Butlerâ€™s injury, the Warriors were on their way to their 12th win in 16 games, having established themselves as a top-5 defense with a still-incandescent Stephen Curry powering the attack.Â Twenty-four hours later, the wound left by Butlerâ€™s absence was gashed wide open. The Warriors gave up 145 points to the visiting Toronto Raptors, the most the Warriors had surrendered in a non-overtime game in over 15 seasons. Reeling from Butlerâ€™s injury on the second night of a back-to-back, they couldnâ€™t stop the bleeding.If there is a silver lining to the Butler torn ACL, it is the calendar. There is no opportune time to tear an ACL, certainly not at Butlerâ€™s age (36), but the Warriors have some time before the Feb. 5 trade deadline to figure out whatâ€™s next.(Hayden Hodge/Yahoo Sports Illustration)At 37, Curry has turned back the clock, improving his scoring average to 27.1 points per game, the most heâ€™s registered since the 2022-23 season. He is now the oldest player to ever average 27 points per game, per Stathead.com tracking. Scoring this much at this age is not something LeBron, KD, MJ or Kobe has ever done. To put it in perspective, Ray Allen, to whom Curry was often compared to earlier in his career, has never averaged 27 points per game, period.Which is why the Warriors have a tough decision ahead of them. Do they maximize Curryâ€™s title window or preserve the post-Curry war chest?Here are three pathways for the Warriors in the aftermath of Butlerâ€™s injury.Path 1: Wait for Butler to come backThe Jimmy Butler trade last year had its doubters, but you canâ€™t deny he changed the Warriorsâ€™ trajectory. Over the last two seasons, with Butler in the lineup, the Warriors are 44-16, which translates to a 55-win pace over 82 games. Without Butler in the lineup, the Warriors are 3-6, which â€¦ not good.For Warriors owner Joe Lacob and general manager Mike Dunleavy Jr., the Curry-Butler-Draymond Green trio is worth clinging to, at least in theory. Butlerâ€™s contract owes him $54 million this season and $57.1 million next season, and there was always a downside that, for all of Butlerâ€™s talents, things could go poorly. Trading for a 35-year-old with hard miles on the tires always comes with risk, even for someone as competitive and fiery as Butler.But the research of Jeff Stotts of InStreetClothes.com canâ€™t be ignored. Since Stotts has meticulously kept tabs on NBA injuries since the 2005-06 season, no player has ever come back from an ACL injury at Butlerâ€™s age. At 36, Butler is the second-oldest player to have suffered the injury, behind only Chris â€œBirdmanâ€ Andersen, who tore his ACL in December of 2016 at 38 years old. Andersen never played again.There is reason for optimism, though. Andersen was never the caliber of player that Butler is. When Andersen tore his ACL, he was playing on a one-year commitment signed for the veteranâ€™s minimum. Without a contract in hand, itâ€™s understandable why Andersen hung it up for good. Butler, on the other hand, has the opportunity to come back to a team led by Curry and Green for one last hurrah. Notably, all three players are on expiring deals next season.[Subscribe to Yahoo Sports NBA on YouTube]Dunleavy has made sure to keep the powder keg dry. The only pick the Warriors owe is a top-20 protected 2030 pick to Washington as part of the Chris Paul trade which will simply convert to a second-round pick if it doesnâ€™t convey. For his part, Dunleavy has said he plans on Butler coming back to the Warriors next season. Dunleavyâ€™s unwillingness to trade first-round picks down the road is a signal that he wants to maintain long-term sustainability rather than go all in for the twilight of Curryâ€™s career. You can read it that way. But there may be another way to view it.Path 2: Trade for another star nowAn alternate interpretation of the Warriorsâ€™ stingy handling of first-round picks: They need them for one last big swing. The Butler contract, with one more year left after this season, could be appealing if another team needs to pivot away from a star player and wants to offload long-term money. Luckily for the Warriors, there are a few options here.Letâ€™s run through a couple.The Anthony Davis trade (and Klay reunion)Warriors receive: Anthony Davis, Klay Thompson, Dante ExumMavericks receive: Jimmy Butler, Jonathan Kuminga and a top-four protected 2028 first-round pick from Golden StateNets receive: Dâ€™Angelo Russell and a lottery-protected 2026 first-round pick from Golden StateIs it risky for Golden State? Yes. Is it sentimental? Sure. Is it a bad idea? I donâ€™t think so. Keeping Butler for the next two seasons may be the easiest but also the worst option on the table. You have to do right by Curry. If he wants to keep contending at the highest level in Golden State, this is a no-brainer.Â Especially since Davis and Curry have a relationship already. Davis, Curry and coach Steve Kerr won gold together in the 2024 Paris Olympics, so itâ€™s not like this would be the first time theyâ€™ve come together to win it all.Â It needs to be pointed out that Davis is out for at least another month with a hand injury. While that timetable is not ideal, one month is way better than the potential 12-month layoff for Butler at the same salary. At 32 years old, Davis is hardly the most reliable star from a player health standpoint, but at least the finger injury wonâ€™t affect his wheels. The same canâ€™t be said for Butler upon his return.Like Butler, Davis would be a floor-raiser star for the Warriors, who are operating on a much different timeline than Dallas now that the Mavs have Cooper Flagg. Davis has a $62.8 million player option for 2027-28, which may not be palatable for Dallas. In Golden State, with Curry still playing at a high level, that might be the price of maximizing Curryâ€™s pursuit for a fifth championship.[Get more Warriors news: Golden State team feed]The Davis acquisition would also help keep Green fresher since neither of them want to play the 5 full-time and they can share the burden of the center position. With Davis occupying the block, a floor-spacing wing like Thompson becomes even more essential. His emotional return would be icing on the cake both in nostalgia and need. WIth deals all expiring in 2026-27, I could see Curry, Green and Thompson taking below-market deals to keep it going.On the Dallas side, the Mavs free themselves of Davisâ€™ monster player option in 2027-28 and take a low-commitment chance on Kuminga, who is still 23 years old. Butlerâ€™s expiring contract could be flipped again at next yearâ€™s deadline to a contender with draft assets. In the meantime, Butler and Kyrie Irving could both rehab from their respective ACL tears. Without control over their first-round picks from 2027 to 2030, the time for Dallasâ€™ ping-pong prioritization is now.To facilitate the deal, the Nets receive Dâ€™Angelo Russell for a third time. Because why not. They could either waive him or keep him for yet another go around on the Russell carousel. For their services, the Warriors would send a heavily protected first-round pick.The Zion Williamson and Trey Murphy III trade (and Kevon Looney reunion)Warriors receive: Zion Williamson, Trey Murphy III and Kevon LooneyPelicans receive: Jimmy Butler, Jonathan Kuminga, two first-round picks (2026 and 2032) and a 2027 first-round pick swapNets receive: Jordan Hawkins and a 2028 top-20 protected pickDunleavy told reporters on Tuesday that he wouldnâ€™t be looking to trade a post-Steph first-round pick unless he was getting a big-time player in return."If we're talking about trading draft picks that will be going out when Steph isn't here, it's going to have to be a player that we think we'll be getting back that is going to be here when those picks are going out," Dunleavy said. "That player's going to have to be pretty impactful. It would take a good amount â€” positionally, play style, archetype, all that. I would leave it pretty broad and open."But if there's a great player to be had, we've got everything in the war chest that we would be willing to use."Do Zion Williamson or Trey Murphy III qualify? Maybe not individually. But if youâ€™re getting both? Absolutely.Â According to Chris Haynes, the Pelicans are not trading their core group, but goodness gracious, the Zion Williamson experience has run its course in New Orleans. The team has lost 14 of its last 16 games with Williamson in uniform (he left Wednesdayâ€™s game early with an illness). The only wins have come against â€¦ Brooklyn and Washington. Itâ€™s way past time to blow it up and move on from the former No. 1 overall pick now that heâ€™s healthy and easier to trade.Williamson and Murphy are both 25 years old and too talented to be floundering on a team clearly building around rookies Jeremiah Fears and Derik Queen. Insert Zion and TM3 in the Warriorsâ€™ championship culture and it wouldnâ€™t surprise me at all to see them blossom into winning contributors on a playoff team. As a bonus, theyâ€™re young enough to be the bridge to the post-Steph era and experienced enough to be win-now players.Of course, like Davis, Williamson is an injury wild card. Taking on a talent like Williamson would be a bet on Warriors director of sports medicine and performance Rick Celebrini to get Williamson back on track and keep him there. Itâ€™s a risk, but would you rather have Butlerâ€™s lost salary and Kuminga or the upside of Williamson and Murphy? I know what I would choose. And Kevon Looney coming back to the Bay? Imagine that standing ovation.As for the Pelicans, they can use the Warriorsâ€™ unprotected 2026 pick as a soft landing from the fallout of trading its 2026 â€œsuper firstâ€ pick to Atlanta that has Milwaukee swap rights. As of now, the Pelicans have no first-round pick in the 2026 draft; the Warriors can change that. While they unload two lob threats for Queen, they acquire one in Kuminga, who is younger, similarly athletic and needs a fresh start.Path 3: Revisit this offseasonButlerâ€™s contract seems like an albatross now, with over $100 million combined coming to him this season and next. But as soon as the NBA fiscal calendar turns this offseason, Butlerâ€™s expiring contract could become a lot more appealing to teams looking to cleanse their long-term cap sheet.Â Would Utah want to move Lauri Markkanenâ€™s long-term deal? What about Cleveland and Evan Mobley if they flame out again? What about Giannis? Those questions may get a hard no now, but that calculus could change over the summer. Especially if Kuminga balls out the rest of the season.While it seems like the Warriors caught a break by having this injury happen now rather than after the deadline, two weeks may be too quick for a Butler market to materialize. There are so many unknowables right now. I would be shocked if Butler hung it up for good like Andersen, especially since he vowed on Instagram to â€œbe back before you know it.â€Questions will be surrounding him for the foreseeable future. Howâ€™s his rehab going? Will he be back in time for the 2026-27 deadline? Will he be back at all for next season?These are questions that donâ€™t have answers now. But this summer, a return-to-play program will come into focus and help teams chart their future. Any team looking to play Butler next season or flip him to a contender will want to know his plan and status for next season as soon as possible. In that sense, two weeks doesnâ€™t seem like a lot of time at all.Â If they take this path, the Warriors could look at the rest of the 2025-26 season as something of a reset. Donâ€™t run Curry and Green into the ground and keep an eye for the future. If it ends up delivering more ping-pong balls on draft night, so be it.Another thing: if the Warriors go all in now, the 2026 first-round pick becomes less attractive to teams. As I mentioned earlier and outlined on the Big Number on Wednesday, the Warriors are 3-6 without Butler in uniform since they acquired him at last yearâ€™s trade deadline. If they continue at a similar pace, they could end up with a lottery pick. Any trade talks involving absorbing Butlerâ€™s contract will become that much sweeter if itâ€™s a known lottery pick as opposed to a late first-rounder.Â With that said, of all the options outlined here, Iâ€™m pushing hard for Path 2. Stephen Curry is the principal reason the Warriors currently rank as the most valuable franchise in the sport. They have to do right by him and go for it while heâ€™s still (inexplicably) an All-NBA player. If Iâ€™m the front office, Iâ€™d call up Pelicans president of basketball operations Joe Dumars and go for the Pelicans move above as a top priority now. If talks donâ€™t result in a move now, it could happen later. Sometimes the trade deadline is just setting the stage for summer fireworks. Stay tuned.
author: Tom Haberstroh

title: Jalen Brunson, Knicks cruise to franchise-best 54-point blowout over Nets days after players only meeting
description: The Knicks entered Wednesday night's game having lost nine of their last 11 games.
content_html: Jalen Brunsonâ€™s players only meeting seems to have worked.Brunson and the New York Knicks cruised to a blowout 120-66 win over the Brooklyn Nets on Wednesday night, which snapped a four-game losing skid. The 54-point win was the largest in franchise history."A win. That was the most important thing, just finding a way to break the ice and get one in the left column," Karl-Anthony Towns said, via The Associated Press. "So good game, good day for us to show what we're capable of, but consistency is what makes champions and we've got to find that consistency and bring this kind of intensity and energy and execution every single night."The Knicks led almost the entire way on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, and they opened the contest on an 18-6 run. They held the Nets to just 18 points in the second quarter, which sent them into the locker room with a 22-point lead, and then pushed that to 32 points by the end of the third period.Brunson and the rest of the Knicks starters were pulled at that point, but their reserves still opened the fourth quarter on a 16-0 tear to secure the blowout win.Brunson had 20 points and five assists to lead the Knicks. Landry Shamet added 18 points off the bench, shooting a perfect 6-of-6 from behind the arc, and Towns added 14 points and eight rebounds. The Knicks shot 50% from behind the arc, and more than doubled the Nets up on the glass.Michael Porter Jr. led the Nets with 12 points and six rebounds. Ziaire Williams was the only other player to hit double figures with his 11 points off the bench. The Nets have now lost 13 straight to the Knicks. Their last win in the series came back in January 2023.While a singular blowout win over the Nets is one thing, it came on the heels of what has been a rough stretch for the Knicks. The team entered Wednesday night having lost nine of their last 11 games, and they were booed heavily at Madison Square Garden in each of their last two losses. After Mondayâ€™s loss to the Dallas Mavericks, Brunson called a meeting to try and turn things around.For the second straight night the Knicks hear loud boos from the MSG crowd. pic.twitter.com/EhWBDKCiosâ€” KNICKS BEAST (@KnicksBeast) January 19, 2026â€œIâ€™d be booing us too, straight up,â€ Brunson said on Monday night.The Knicks now hold a 26-18 record entering Saturday nightâ€™s contest with the Philadelphia 76ers. That game, while just a mid-January bout, will be a better measure of if the meeting actually did its job."This was a good step for us, but we've got to continue to press the issue of getting better every single day,â€ Brunson said.
author: Ryan Young

title: Jeanie Buss reportedly felt LeBron James wasn't grateful enough after Lakers took son Bronny in NBA Draft
description: Jeanie Buss reportedly soured on LeBron James after the Russell Westbrook trade.
content_html: The Los Angeles Lakers returned to notoriety when the team signed superstar LeBron James in free agency ahead of the 2018-19 NBA season. While that partnership turned out well initially â€” with James leading the team to a championship in his second season â€” Lakers owner Jeanie Buss reportedly began to sour on James, per ESPN's Baxter Holmes.Â That tidbit was revealed as part of a much larger piece on the Buss' family drama and how it led to the team being sold to Mark Walter. While there are plenty of juicy revelations in the article, Buss' relationship with James will likely draw the most attention.Buss' opinion of James reportedly started to change after the Lakers traded for Russell Westbrook in 2021. The move, which the team made to make James happy, backfired. Westbook's fit on the Lakers was awkward, and the team failed to make the playoffs after acquiring the veteran. Buss reportedly was frustrated with the way James washed his hands of the deal and blamed others after it failed, per ESPN.[Get more Lakers news: Los Angeles team feed]Buss reportedly even considered trading James at one point â€” with the Los Angeles Clippers being the most likely destination. That didn't happen, and James inserted a no-trade clause into his 2024 extension, making a deal impossible now unless James approves it.Â The relationship further soured after the Lakers drafted James' son, Bronny, in the second round of the 2024 NBA Draft. Buss reportedly felt LeBron should have been more grateful the team picked his son in the draft, per ESPN."And when the Lakers drafted James' son, Bronny, with the 55th pick in the 2024 draft, Jeanie privately remarked that James should be grateful for such a gesture, but she felt that he wasn't, people close to the team told ESPN."Bronny, 21, has been used in a reserve role in the NBA. He's averaged 1.9 points in 51 career games.Â Buss released a statement to The Athletic refuting the claim about James, saying: â€œItâ€™s really not right, given all the great things LeBron has done for the Lakers, that he has to be pulled into my family drama. To say that it wasnâ€™t appreciated is just not true and completely unfair to him.â€But if the report is true, Buss and James could be heading for a clean break in the offseason. James' contract is up at the end of the season, allowing the 41-year-old to easily leave the team in the offseason. James has still performed well this season and has helped the Lakers to a 26-16 start. If he wants to keep playing, James could almost certainly find a job with another franchise.But it's unclear whether James will do that. The 23-year veteran has not addressed his future in the NBA past the 2025-26 season.Â If James does come back for one more year, it's possible he once again considers the Lakers. But if Wednesday's report is accurate, James' return to Los Angeles could be dependent on whether Buss, who remains the team's governor and minority owner, can still co-exist with the superstar.
author: Chris Cwik

title: 2025 NBA trade season: Should the Pistons and Spurs go all in at the deadline?
description: With the trade deadline approaching, we ponder the teams and situations that could be active.
content_html: The NBA trade deadline is Feb. 5. Letâ€™s dive into the chatter and try to make sense of it all.Â Morten Stig Jensen: All right, Kelly. The NBA trade deadline is just two weeks away, and we've already seen Trae Young change addresses, with Ja Morant and Anthony Davis rumored to follow suit.Â But instead of regurgitating those same two names, I'm wondering if we should identify teams that are just generally in need of doing â€¦ well, something!Detroit is No. 1 in the East, and that's obviously good, but I can't escape the feeling they aren't that heavy in the talent department.Â [Subscribe to Yahoo Sports NBA on YouTube]Tobias Harrisâ€™ expiring contract, worth over $26.6 million, could be a big trade chip, and now is the time to do something as Jalen Duren is going to earn a new paycheck this coming summer.Â Lauri Markkanen is a name often bandied about in connection with the Pistons, but should they even try to enter into negotiations with Danny Ainge?Â Kelly Iko: The Pistons are having a historic season, are loaded with young talent and have the leagueâ€™s second-ranked defense. It would be an absolute buzzkill for them to stand pat before the trade deadline.Â From an offensive standpoint, Detroit is kind of meh. Theyâ€™re 26th in offensive rating since Jan. 1, 23rd in halfcourt points per possession, 26th in 3-point attempt rate and 22nd in 3-point makes.Â In a perfect world, Cade Cunningham would be this prolific driver, drawing downhill gravity and spraying out to shooters on the perimeter who could either knock down catch-and-shoot looks or create their own if the defense adjusts. According to Second Spectrum, Cunningham is fifth in drives per game (16.8), but the difference between him and, say, Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, is stark. Cunningham shoots 10% worse on drives and 10% worse at the free-throw line than SGA.The playoffs are essentially a math problem and when the book is out on Detroit â€” swarm Cunningham at the point of attack and dare their role players to make shots â€” the issues could come quickly. Houstonâ€™s 2024-25 season comes to mind: exciting young core with a kick-ass defense that struggles in the halfcourt. That was a first-round exit.Â Pistons ratingsSo yes, I think Markkanen makes sense in a lot of ways as a jumbo creator with uber-spacing ability. Ditto for Michael Porter Jr. and Trey Murphy. Yahoo Sportsâ€™ Kevin Oâ€™Connor recently put together a nice list of names the Pistons should be chasing, but the overarching theme is as awesome as Detroit has been for a refreshing storyline, this is anything but a perfect team.Â Back to you, Mort. Whoâ€™s second on your list and why? Perhaps a team out West â€¦Mort: Sir, if you're insinuating that I should bring up the Spurs here, I shan't disappoint. This team is just so far ahead of where most had them pegged at this stage, and that leads to a similar conclusion as you had with Detroit. It'd be a buzzkill if they didn't do, well, something.So let me throw something your way that's proper insanity.Â The Spurs need a more-than-solid wing big if they are to constantly go up against the Oklahoma City Thunder. We can sit here all day and talk about short-term solutions and who might come cheaper on the trade front, but let's kill that noise and go all in.Â Deni Avdija.Â The Blazers have zero â€” and I mean ZERO â€” interest in moving off their 26/7/7 wing, who should make his first All-Star team this season.As such, the Spurs need to make what we rarely see anymore: the Godfather offer.Â Kelly Olynyk for salary-matching and damn near every tradable pick under the sun, in particular the juicy ones, such as Atlanta's 2027, a future Kings swap option and some of their own in the 2030s.They're clearly moving off Jeremy Sochan, and while Harrison Barnes is one of the best role players in the league, he's getting up there in age. There's going to be a need for a wing big who can play power forward, and they need someone who can shoot, handle the ball and initiate plays in such a role.Â Why not make a play for a guy who fits the timeline, is dirt cheap ($13.1 million in 2026-2027 and $11.8 million in 2027-28) and could realistically catapult you into championship contention this very season?Â At the very least, the Blazers can receive the offer. If they wish to stick with Avdija, which I think we both could understand, then so be it. But it'd show some aggressiveness on behalf of the Spurs in trying to fulfill their mission as soon as possible and while Victor Wembanyama is still young and (relatively) healthy.Â (I don't want to put the injury hex on him, but let's be real. Human beings who are 7-feet-5 and play professional sports historically play fewer years than, say, smaller lead guards.)Iko: Love the idea of Avdija in San Antonio. So much of what the Spurs do â€” from a non-Wemby and offensive balance vantage point â€” revolves around the proficiency of their guard play. Bringing in a taller initiator with legit three-level scoring ability would give them an added wrinkle while still keeping their spacing in Devin Vassell and Julian Champagnie.Â Hereâ€™s my devilâ€™s advocate question for you, though. We just named two teams that could benefit from pulling the trade trigger. But what about the teams that would be letting these assets go? Is there a world where the Blazers ponder what Avdija looks like next to a healthy Damian Lillard? Is there a world where the Jazz start to actually build around Markkanen and Keyonte George? Or are those teams destined for NBA purgatory and should flip their hot commodities while they still can?Â Mort: I usually want teams in NBA purgatory to not go all in, as that often insinuates they don't have their leading man.Â (Neither the Blazers nor Jazz are in purgatory due to their situations, but it's fair to wonder if their ultimate ceiling is capped as none of Avdija, Markkanen or George projects as a Tier 1 superstar.)Â However.Â Allow me to just bring up the Bulls for a second. We don't assume competence on their part, and probably rightly so, but have you seen the situation they're in?Â If new leadership were to take over, it'd be licking its chops: an enormous bundle of expiring contracts, upward of $80-plus million, control of all of their picks and even some youngsters with trade value.Â Is this a team that should take a step back and build even more draft equity? Probably, but that's never been its favorite song. Instead, this leadership has a history of buying and leaning into some questionable upgrades, such as Nikola VuÄeviÄ‡ at the trade deadline in 2021, when they then followed up in free agency by acquiring both Lonzo Ball and DeMar DeRozan.Â Is this on-the-fence team one we should keep an eye on?Â Generally speaking, I'm curious how teams with numerous trade assets will decide to act before Feb. 5. Do they see this as a means of buying low on, say, Zion Williamson or Ja Morant?Â Williamson is reportedly off the table in trade negotiations, but excuse my French when I say, â€œBaloney!â€Â Personally, I don't think it's a smart strategy, but reasonable people can disagree, and we must at least acknowledge there is star quality attached to both names.Â Iko: Ironically, we talked about Chicago prior to the season. These sneaky Bulls always mosey their way into the conversation.Iâ€™m generally wary of anything going on in the Windy City (DJ Moore routes included), but if Iâ€™m in the Bullsâ€™ front office and Iâ€™m pondering whether to make a move for Morant or Williamson, why not just go for both?Â It sounds ludicrous until you actually give it some thought. Health and availability is obviously the biggest factor in moving for either of these players, but theyâ€™re still young enough (Zion, 25; Morant, 26) where you could sell a core along with Matas Buzelis, whoâ€™s been a bright spot and showcased some underrated defensive versatility. Again, this only works if you can guarantee that both play in at least 65 games (big if), but Iâ€™m tired of the Bulls being boring. Shoot for the oft-injured stars.Â On a more serious note, I appreciate how each team approaches this time of the year. The rumor mill can get a bit mundane, but at least if you sift through enough, youâ€™ll get an understanding of individual organizational goals and objectives. It should be a fun two weeks.
author: Morten Stig Jensen,Kelly Iko

title: NBA midseason grades: Report cards for every East team, plus each roster's MVP so far
description: Which East teams deserve the highest marks at the regular season's midway point?
content_html: Every team in the Eastern Conference has played at least 41 games, which means we have reached the NBA regular seasonâ€™s midway point, which means it is high time for a report card. (Our midseason awards can be found here.)The Detroit Pistons (31-10), led on offense by Cade Cunningham and owners of the Eastâ€™s best defense, are running away with the No. 1 seed, holding on to a 5.5-game lead in the conference.Still, the East is as wide open as it has ever been. The second-place and surprising Boston Celtics (26-16) could return Jayson Tatum for the fourth quarter of this season. The New York Knicks (25-18) have been floundering, but we know what they are capable of when they are firing on all cylinders. Same goes for the sloooowly getting better Cleveland Cavaliers (24-20).[Subscribe to Yahoo Sports NBA on YouTube]Meanwhile, the Philadelphia 76ers (23-19) and Orlando Magic (23-19) are lurking, if only they could stay healthy. Then there are the Toronto Raptors (26-19), who are as plucky as anybody.We have yet to see a team in the East that has made the statement: We are prepared to battle whomever emerges from the Western Conference in the NBA Finals. Maybe Detroit is THEM. The Pistons could use one more impact player, but that is for the trade deadline to determine.Now, though, it is time to get to the grades â€¦Atlanta Hawks â€¢ Boston Celtics â€¢ Brooklyn Nets â€¢ Charlotte Hornets â€¢ Chicago Bulls â€¢ Cleveland Cavaliers â€¢ Detroit Pistons â€¢ Indiana Pacers â€¢ Miami Heat â€¢ Milwaukee Bucks â€¢ New York Knicks â€¢ Orlando Magic â€¢ Philadelphia 76ers â€¢ Toronto Raptors â€¢ Washington Wizards(Our first-quarter grades can be found here.)(Mallory Bielecki/Yahoo Sports Illustration)Atlanta Hawks (20-25)Midseason MVP: Jalen Johnson (23-10-8 on 51/36/78)Offensive rating: 113.4 (22nd) â€¢ Defensive rating: 114.8 (16th)Best lineup: Johnson â€¢Â Nickeil Alexander-Walker â€¢ Dyson Daniels â€¢ Zaccharie Risacher â€¢Â Kristaps PorziÅ†Ä£is (+19 in 129 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 11-18 â€¢ Against losing teams: 9-7Comments: Since trading Trae Young, the Hawks are 3-4, hardly the start they anticipated upon dealing the four-time All-Star point guard. â€¦ On the whole, they have been outscored by 1.4 points per 100 meaningful possessions when Young is not on the court, per Cleaning the Glass. â€¦ Atlanta was supposed to be a darkhorse candidate to emerge from the East. Instead, it looks like it could be bound for the play-in again. â€¦ Is another big move in development?Grade: DBoston Celtics (26-16)Midseason MVP: Jaylen Brown (30-7-5 on 49/36/79)Offensive rating: 121.4 (2nd) â€¢ Defensive rating: 114.0 (14th)Best lineup: Brown â€¢ Payton Pritchard â€¢ Derrick White â€¢ Sam Hauser â€¢ Neemias Queta (+53 in 134 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 13-12 â€¢ Against author: Ben Rohrbach

title: Lakers center DeAndre Ayton shows off new look after leaving game due to eye poke: 'He looks like a pirate'
description: Deandre Ayton could be back in time for the Lakers' next game.
content_html: Los Angeles Lakers big man Deandre Ayton is temporarily adopting a new look. After leaving Tuesday's contest due to an eye poke, Ayton posted a photo on Instagram in which he's wearing a patch over his eye.On the photo, Ayton added a pirate emoji, poking fun at his appearance.From Deandreâ€™s IG: https://t.co/BVi0xIjnXgpic.twitter.com/fnXvfYnQonâ€” Dave McMenamin (@mcten) January 21, 2026He was far from the only member of the Lakers to make that comparison. After the contest, Lakers head coach JJ Redick said Ayton looked "like a pirate" after leaving the contest just before halftime.Â Ayton did not play the entire third quarter due to the injury. Before the fourth quarter was over, the Lakers announced he would miss the rest of the contest. He finished with four points and eight rebounds in roughly 15 minutes during the Lakers' 115-107 win over the Denver Nuggets.While Redick said Ayton's eye was "not in good shape" after the game, the team doesn't expect Ayton to miss time. Redick added that the center "will be fine" ahead of Thursday's game against the Los Angeles Clippers. Even if Ayton needs to miss that game, it doesn't sound like the eye injury will keep him sidelined for long.Â After spending the last two seasons with the Portland Trail Blazers, Ayton joined the Lakers on a two-year deal in the offseason. He's put up his usual numbers through 37 games with the team, averaging 13.9 points and 8.8 rebounds.
author: Chris Cwik

title: Warriors GM Mike Dunleavy Jr. not planning to deal Jimmy Butler's contract, ponders Jonathan Kuminga's trade value: 'There needs to be demand'
description: The NBA trade deadline is Feb. 5. The Warriors have a lot to figure out before then.
content_html: Jimmy Butler's ACL tear is a devastating blow for the veteran All-Star and cause for a reckoning in Golden State over its plans to compete in the back-end of Stephen Curry's prime.Â General manager Mike Dunleavy was on hand Tuesday night to address the Warriors' short- and long-term plans ahead of Golden State's home game against the Toronto Raptors.He was asked about Butler's future with the franchise as well as that of disgruntled forward Jonathan Kuminga, who's been languishing on the bench amid poor play and a trade demand. And ... let's just say that he has divergent thoughts on Butler's and Kuminga's value on the basketball court.Dunleavy not ready to tear things downWith Butler's injury prompting chatter of a full teardown and the end of the era of competitive basketball with Curry, Dunleavy was asked about the prospect of trading away Butler's contract, which has one year and $56.8 million remaining beyond this season.Â Dunleavy said that he's not entertaining the idea.Â Â "I don't envision that," Dunleavy said. "But now that you've brought it up, I guess I'd say what I envision for him is kind of giving us a boost next year the same way he did last year when he arrived.Â "And so, at some point during the season, him returning and being the player he's been."Mike Dunleavy said he does not envision he will trade Jimmy Butlerâ€™s contract and believes Butler will rehab and return to help the team at some point next season pic.twitter.com/FjU1xzDnb6â€” Anthony Slater (@anthonyVslater) January 21, 2026That sounds like a man not ready to wave the white flag on the Curry era. It also sounds like the words of an optimist. Butler will be 37 next season and coming off one of the most serious injuries in sports.Â Can Butler return to high-level basketball after ACL tear?Butler's been a boon for the Warriors and helped spark a run to the second round of the playoffs last season after arriving via a midseason trade. The Warriors made the playoffs as the No. 7 seed out of the play-in, then upset the No. 2 seed Rockets in the first round before falling to the Timberwolves in the second.Â Butler's arrival was a big reason for that success, and he was playing at an All-Star level this season (20 ppg, 5.6 rpg, 4.9 apg, 1.4 spg) before tearing his right ACL Monday night. If anyone's capable of returning from an ACL tear to play at a high level at 37 years old, Butler's the type of player to do it. And for now, at least, Dunleavy appears to be holding out hope that that's how things play out.The alternative is not an appealing option and one that could mean dealing Curry while he still has trade value. They are not ready for that in Golden State.Â What about Kuminga?As for the short-term, Butler's minutes just opened up, and they need to be filled. That could mean the end of Kuminga's relegation to the bench. Head coach Steve Kerr opened the door to that possibility, telling reporters that Kuminga "could be" part of the rotation in Butler's absence.Â That would require a willingness on both sides to thaw an icy relationship. Dunleavy doesn't sound eager to extend an olive branch. When asked about Kuminga's trade demand, Dunleavy suggested that Kuminga might not drum up much demand for his services."As far as the demand, I'm aware of that. In terms of demands, when you make a demand, there needs to be demand â€” on the market."Warriors GM Mike Dunleavy Jr. with a candid quote on Jonathan Kuminga's trade demand. pic.twitter.com/7iNoKxpd2zâ€” KNBR (@KNBR) January 21, 2026"I think as far as the demand â€” I'm aware of that," Dunleavy said. "I think in terms of demands, when you make a demand, there needs to be demand on the market. So, we'll see where that unfolds.The NBA trade deadline is Feb. 5. The Warriors have a lot to figure out before then.
author: Jason Owens

title: Jeanie Buss reportedly felt LeBron James wasn't grateful enough after Lakers took son Bronny in NBA Draft
description: Jeanie Buss reportedly soured on LeBron James after the Russell Westbrook trade.
content_html: The Los Angeles Lakers returned to notoriety when the team signed superstar LeBron James in free agency ahead of the 2018-19 NBA season. While that partnership turned out well initially â€” with James leading the team to a championship in his second season â€” Lakers owner Jeanie Buss reportedly began to sour on James, per ESPN's Baxter Holmes.Â That tidbit was revealed as part of a much larger piece on the Buss' family drama and how it led to the team being sold to Mark Walter. While there are plenty of juicy revelations in the article, Buss' relationship with James will likely draw the most attention.Buss' opinion of James reportedly started to change after the Lakers traded for Russell Westbrook in 2021. The move, which the team made to make James happy, backfired. Westbook's fit on the Lakers was awkward, and the team failed to make the playoffs after acquiring the veteran. Buss reportedly was frustrated with the way James washed his hands of the deal and blamed others after it failed, per ESPN.[Get more Lakers news: Los Angeles team feed]Buss reportedly even considered trading James at one point â€” with the Los Angeles Clippers being the most likely destination. That didn't happen, and James inserted a no-trade clause into his 2024 extension, making a deal impossible now unless James approves it.Â The relationship further soured after the Lakers drafted James' son, Bronny, in the second round of the 2024 NBA Draft. Buss reportedly felt LeBron should have been more grateful the team picked his son in the draft, per ESPN."And when the Lakers drafted James' son, Bronny, with the 55th pick in the 2024 draft, Jeanie privately remarked that James should be grateful for such a gesture, but she felt that he wasn't, people close to the team told ESPN."Bronny, 21, has been used in a reserve role in the NBA. He's averaged 1.9 points in 51 career games.Â If those reports are true, Buss and James could be heading for a clean break in the offseason. James' contract is up at the end of the season, allowing the 41-year-old to easily leave the team in the offseason. James has still performed well this season and has helped the Lakers to a 26-16 start. If he wants to keep playing, James could almost certainly find a job with another franchise.But it's unclear whether James will do that. The 23-year veteran has not addressed his future in the NBA past the 2025-26 season.Â If James does come back for one more year, it's possible he once again considers the Lakers. But if Wednesday's report is accurate, James' return to Los Angeles could be dependent on whether Buss, who remains the team's governor and minority owner, can still co-exist with the superstar.
author: Chris Cwik

title: 2025 NBA trade season: Should the Pistons and Spurs go all in at the deadline?
description: With the trade deadline approaching, we ponder the teams and situations that could be active.
content_html: The NBA trade deadline is Feb. 5. Letâ€™s dive into the chatter and try to make sense of it all.Â Morten Stig Jensen: All right, Kelly. The NBA trade deadline is just two weeks away, and we've already seen Trae Young change addresses, with Ja Morant and Anthony Davis rumored to follow suit.Â But instead of regurgitating those same two names, I'm wondering if we should identify teams that are just generally in need of doing â€¦ well, something!Detroit is No. 1 in the East, and that's obviously good, but I can't escape the feeling they aren't that heavy in the talent department.Â [Subscribe to Yahoo Sports NBA on YouTube]Tobias Harrisâ€™ expiring contract, worth over $26.6 million, could be a big trade chip, and now is the time to do something as Jalen Duren is going to earn a new paycheck this coming summer.Â Lauri Markkanen is a name often bandied about in connection with the Pistons, but should they even try to enter into negotiations with Danny Ainge?Â Kelly Iko: The Pistons are having a historic season, are loaded with young talent and have the leagueâ€™s second-ranked defense. It would be an absolute buzzkill for them to stand pat before the trade deadline.Â From an offensive standpoint, Detroit is kind of meh. Theyâ€™re 26th in offensive rating since Jan. 1, 23rd in halfcourt points per possession, 26th in 3-point attempt rate and 22nd in 3-point makes.Â In a perfect world, Cade Cunningham would be this prolific driver, drawing downhill gravity and spraying out to shooters on the perimeter who could either knock down catch-and-shoot looks or create their own if the defense adjusts. According to Second Spectrum, Cunningham is fifth in drives per game (16.8), but the difference between him and, say, Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, is stark. Cunningham shoots 10% worse on drives and 10% worse at the free-throw line than SGA.The playoffs are essentially a math problem and when the book is out on Detroit â€” swarm Cunningham at the point of attack and dare their role players to make shots â€” the issues could come quickly. Houstonâ€™s 2024-25 season comes to mind: exciting young core with a kick-ass defense that struggles in the halfcourt. That was a first-round exit.Â So yes, I think Markkanen makes sense in a lot of ways as a jumbo creator with uber-spacing ability. Ditto for Michael Porter Jr. and Trey Murphy. Yahoo Sportsâ€™ Kevin Oâ€™Connor recently put together a nice list of names the Pistons should be chasing, but the overarching theme is as awesome as Detroit has been for a refreshing storyline, this is anything but a perfect team.Â Back to you, Mort. Whoâ€™s second on your list and why? Perhaps a team out West â€¦Mort: Sir, if you're insinuating that I should bring up the Spurs here, I shan't disappoint. This team is just so far ahead of where most had them pegged at this stage, and that leads to a similar conclusion as you had with Detroit. It'd be a buzzkill if they didn't do, well, something.So let me throw something your way that's proper insanity.Â The Spurs need a more-than-solid wing big if they are to constantly go up against the Oklahoma City Thunder. We can sit here all day and talk about short-term solutions and who might come cheaper on the trade front, but let's kill that noise and go all in.Â Deni Avdija.Â The Blazers have zero â€” and I mean ZERO â€” interest in moving off their 26/7/7 wing, who should make his first All-Star team this season.As such, the Spurs need to make what we rarely see anymore: the Godfather offer.Â Kelly Olynyk for salary-matching and damn near every tradable pick under the sun, in particular the juicy ones, such as Atlanta's 2027, a future Kings swap option and some of their own in the 2030s.They're clearly moving off Jeremy Sochan, and while Harrison Barnes is one of the best role players in the league, he's getting up there in age. There's going to be a need for a wing big who can play power forward, and they need someone who can shoot, handle the ball and initiate plays in such a role.Â Why not make a play for a guy who fits the timeline, is dirt cheap ($13.1 million in 2026-2027 and $11.8 million in 2027-28) and could realistically catapult you into championship contention this very season?Â At the very least, the Blazers can receive the offer. If they wish to stick with Avdija, which I think we both could understand, then so be it. But it'd show some aggressiveness on behalf of the Spurs in trying to fulfill their mission as soon as possible and while Victor Wembanyama is still young and (relatively) healthy.Â (I don't want to put the injury hex on him, but let's be real. Human beings who are 7-feet-5 and play professional sports historically play fewer years than, say, smaller lead guards.)Iko: Love the idea of Avdija in San Antonio. So much of what the Spurs do â€” from a non-Wemby and offensive balance vantage point â€” revolves around the proficiency of their guard play. Bringing in a taller initiator with legit three-level scoring ability would give them an added wrinkle while still keeping their spacing in Devin Vassell and Julian Champagnie.Â Hereâ€™s my devilâ€™s advocate question for you, though. We just named two teams that could benefit from pulling the trade trigger. But what about the teams that would be letting these assets go? Is there a world where the Blazers ponder what Avdija looks like next to a healthy Damian Lillard? Is there a world where the Jazz start to actually build around Markkanen and Keyonte George? Or are those teams destined for NBA purgatory and should flip their hot commodities while they still can?Â Mort: I usually want teams in NBA purgatory to not go all in, as that often insinuates they don't have their leading man.Â (Neither the Blazers nor Jazz are in purgatory due to their situations, but it's fair to wonder if their ultimate ceiling is capped as none of Avdija, Markkanen or George projects as a Tier 1 superstar.)Â However.Â Allow me to just bring up the Bulls for a second. We don't assume competence on their part, and probably rightly so, but have you seen the situation they're in?Â If new leadership were to take over, it'd be licking its chops: an enormous bundle of expiring contracts, upward of $80-plus million, control of all of their picks and even some youngsters with trade value.Â Is this a team that should take a step back and build even more draft equity? Probably, but that's never been its favorite song. Instead, this leadership has a history of buying and leaning into some questionable upgrades, such as Nikola VuÄeviÄ‡ at the trade deadline in 2021, when they then followed up in free agency by acquiring both Lonzo Ball and DeMar DeRozan.Â Is this on-the-fence team one we should keep an eye on?Â Generally speaking, I'm curious how teams with numerous trade assets will decide to act before Feb. 5. Do they see this as a means of buying low on, say, Zion Williamson or Ja Morant?Â Williamson is reportedly off the table in trade negotiations, but excuse my French when I say, â€œBaloney!â€Â Personally, I don't think it's a smart strategy, but reasonable people can disagree, and we must at least acknowledge there is star quality attached to both names.Â Iko: Ironically, we talked about Chicago prior to the season. These sneaky Bulls always mosey their way into the conversation.Iâ€™m generally wary of anything going on in the Windy City (DJ Moore routes included), but if Iâ€™m in the Bullsâ€™ front office and Iâ€™m pondering whether to make a move for Morant or Williamson, why not just go for both?Â It sounds ludicrous until you actually give it some thought. Health and availability is obviously the biggest factor in moving for either of these players, but theyâ€™re still young enough (Zion, 25; Morant, 26) where you could sell a core along with rookie Matas Buzelis, whoâ€™s been a bright spot and showcased some underrated defensive versatility. Again, this only works if you can guarantee that both play in at least 65 games (big if), but Iâ€™m tired of the Bulls being boring. Shoot for the oft-injured stars.Â On a more serious note, I appreciate how each team approaches this time of the year. The rumor mill can get a bit mundane, but at least if you sift through enough, youâ€™ll get an understanding of individual organizational goals and objectives. It should be a fun two weeks.
author: Morten Stig Jensen,Kelly Iko

Is the criticism of Karl-Anthony Towns fair, or should Mike Brown shoulder the blame?(1:06) The Big Number: Jimmy Butler out for the season(28:08) The Little Numbers: Warriors offense without Butler(32:44) The Little Numbers: Draymond Green's salary(36:53) The Little Numbers: Golden State's playoff odds(42:56) Is KAT what's wrong with the Knicks?JANUARY 19: Jimmy Butler III of Warriors warms up during the pregame of the NBA game 23 between Miami Heat and Golden State Warriors in San Francisco at Chase Center on January 19, 2026 in San Francisco, California, United States. title: NBA midseason grades: Report cards for every East team, plus each roster's MVP so far
description: Which East teams deserve the highest marks at the regular seasonâ€™s midway point?
content_html: Every team in the Eastern Conference has played at least 41 games, which means we have reached the NBA regular seasonâ€™s midway point, which means it is high time for a report card. (Our midseason awards can be found here.)The Detroit Pistons (31-10), led on offense by Cade Cunningham and owners of the Eastâ€™s best defense, are running away with the No. 1 seed, holding on to a 5.5-game lead in the conference.Still, the East is as wide open as it has ever been. The second-place and surprising Boston Celtics (26-16) could return Jayson Tatum for the fourth quarter of this season. The New York Knicks (25-18) have been floundering, but we know what they are capable of when they are firing on all cylinders. Same goes for the sloooowly-getting-better Cleveland Cavaliers (24-20).[Subscribe to Yahoo Sports NBA on YouTube]Meanwhile, the Philadelphia 76ers (23-19) and Orlando Magic (23-19) are lurking, if only they could stay healthy. Then there are the Toronto Raptors (26-19), who are as plucky as anybody.We have yet to see a team in the East that has made the statement: We are prepared to battle whomever emerges from the Western Conference in the NBA Finals. Maybe Detroit is THEM. The Pistons could use one more impact player, but that is for the trade deadline to determine.Now, though, it is time to get to the grades â€¦Atlanta Hawks â€¢ Boston Celtics â€¢ Brooklyn Nets â€¢ Charlotte Hornets â€¢ Chicago Bulls â€¢ Cleveland Cavaliers â€¢ Detroit Pistons â€¢ Indiana Pacers â€¢ Miami Heat â€¢ Milwaukee Bucks â€¢ New York Knicks â€¢ Orlando Magic â€¢ Philadelphia 76ers â€¢ Toronto Raptors â€¢ Washington Wizards(Our first-quarter grades can be found here.)(Mallory Bielecki/Yahoo Sports Illustration)Atlanta Hawks (20-25)Midseason MVP: Jalen Johnson (23-10-8 on 51/36/78)Offensive rating: 113.4 (22nd) â€¢ Defensive rating: 114.8 (16th)Best lineup: Johnson â€¢Â Nickeil Alexander-Walker â€¢ Dyson Daniels â€¢ Zaccharie Risacher â€¢Â Kristaps PorziÅ†Ä£is (+19 in 129 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 11-18 â€¢ Against losing teams: 9-7Comments: Since trading Trae Young, the Hawks are 3-4, hardly the start they anticipated upon dealing the four-time All-Star point guard. â€¦ On the whole, they have been outscored by 1.4 points per 100 meaningful possessions when Young is not on the court, per Cleaning the Glass. â€¦ Atlanta was supposed to be a darkhorse candidate to emerge from the East. Instead, it looks like it could be bound for the play-in again. â€¦ Is another big move in development?Grade: DBoston Celtics (26-16)Midseason MVP: Jaylen Brown (30-7-5 on 49/36/79)Offensive rating: 121.4 (2nd) â€¢ Defensive rating: 114.0 (14th)Best lineup: Brown â€¢ Payton Pritchard â€¢ Derrick White â€¢ Sam Hauser â€¢ Neemias Queta (+53 in 134 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 13-12 â€¢ Against losing teams: 13-4Comments: The Celtics own the Eastâ€™s second-best record and its second-best net rating, all in the absence of an injured Jayson Tatum. â€¦ Tatumâ€™s return could be sooner than later. â€¦ Jaylen Brown has played his way into the MVP conversation. â€¦ Anfernee Simons and Sam Hauser have also played well enough for the Celtics to consider a) not moving either at the deadline or b) packaging one or both of them, along with picks, for a significant upgrade. â€¦ They could use another big.Grade: ABrooklyn Nets (12-29)Midseason MVP: Michael Porter Jr. (26-7-3 on 49/40/85)Offensive rating: 112.3 (25th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 117.4 (26th)Best lineup: Porter â€¢ Egor Demin â€¢ Tre Mann â€¢ Noah Clowney â€¢ Nicolas Claxton (+18 in 306 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 5-18 â€¢ Against losing teams: 7-11Comments: The Nets may have won their trade of Cam Johnson, given how well Michael Porter Jr. has played to this point and the fact that they received an additional first-round pick in the deal. â€¦ Porter might fetch more first-round assets if he is shopped by the deadline. â€¦ The Nets needed one of their five first-round picks to pop, and none of them have, though Egor Demin has played better of late (14-3-3 on 45/45/83 shooting splits in his last 14 appearances).Grade: CCharlotte Hornets (16-27)Midseason MVP: Kon Knueppel (19-5-4 on 49/44/89)Offensive rating: 116.9 (7th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 116.7 (21st)Best lineup: Knueppel â€¢ LaMelo Ball â€¢ Brandon Miller â€¢ Miles Bridges â€¢ Moussa Diabate (+63 in 112 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 7-16 â€¢ Against losing teams: 9-11Comments: Rookie wing Kon Knueppel, it seems, was a true find at the No. 4 draft slot. â€¦ Brandon Miller should be good, too. Together they are a decent foundation. â€¦ Is LaMelo Ball a part of that same foundation? He is reportedly open to a trade away from Charlotte, and it might be in the Hornetsâ€™ best interest to deal him. â€¦ They have not won with him. â€¦ Then again, they are +11.5 points per 100 meaningful possessions when Knueppel, Miller and Ball share a court.Grade: DChicago Bulls (21-22)Midseason MVP: Josh Giddey (19-9-9 on 47/39/76)Offensive rating: 114.4 (16th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 116.8 (23rd)Best lineup: Giddey â€¢ Matas Buzelis â€¢ Kevin Huerter â€¢ Isaac Okoro â€¢ Nikola VuÄeviÄ‡ (+5 in 65 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 10-11 â€¢ Against losing teams: 11-11Comments: Shocker of all shockers: The Bulls are hovering around .500 again, bound for another play-in tournament in a watered-down Eastern Conference, no chance at winning. â€¦ Lots to like about Matas Buzelis. â€¦ You canâ€™t help but appreciate Nikola VuÄeviÄ‡â€™s efforts, too, even as he seems endlessly frustrated by Chicagoâ€™s perpetual quest for mediocrity. â€¦ What to do with Coby White, a 2026 free agent? â€¦ The Bulls are full of questions, empty of answers.Â Grade: DCleveland Cavaliers (24-20)Midseason MVP: Donovan Mitchell (29-5-6 on 49/38/84)Offensive rating: 116.5 (10th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 114.6 (15th)Best lineup: Mitchell â€¢ Darius Garland â€¢ Deâ€™Andre Hunter â€¢ Evan Mobley â€¢ Jarrett Allen (+29 in 51 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 10-15 â€¢ Against losing teams: 14-5Comments: That redundancy of Donovan Mitchell and Darius Garland in the backcourt and Evan Mobley and Jarrett Allen in the frontcourt? Still a problem. â€¦ Far more of a problem than it was a year ago at this time, when the Cavs were bound for a 64-win campaign. â€¦ Then again, when all four are on the court, Cleveland is still +7.2 points per 100 meaningful possessions. â€¦ Maybe they need a wing. â€¦ Maybe they just need Garland healthy. â€¦ They need something.Grade: CDetroit Pistons (31-10)Midseason MVP: Cade Cunningham (26-6-10 on 45/33/82)Offensive rating: 116.0 (11th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 108.5 (2nd)Best lineup: Cunningham â€¢Â Ausar Thompson â€¢ Duncan Robinson â€¢ Tobias Harris â€¢ Jalen Duren (+57 in 276 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 14-4 â€¢ Against losing teams: 17-6Comments: The Pistons own the Eastâ€™s best record and best net rating. How could we complain? â€¦ Cade Cunningham has been everything Detroit could have asked for from its No. 1 pick. â€¦ Jalen Duren should be an All-Star. â€¦ They need to upgrade the Tobias Harris position if they want to seriously compete with the West. â€¦ Lauri Markkanen would be nice, but his cost is prohibitive. â€¦ Michael Porter Jr.? Now, he would establish them as clear favorites in the East.Grade: AIndiana Pacers (10-34)Midseason MVP: Pascal Siakam (24-7-4 on 48/38/68)Offensive rating: 107.9 (30th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 116.0 (19th)Best lineup: Siakam â€¢Â Andrew Nembhard â€¢ Ben Sheppard â€¢ Bennedict Mathurin â€¢ Jay Huff (+9 in 39 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 3-25 â€¢ Against losing teams: 7-9Comments: Look at what the Celtics have done without Tatum, and look at what the Pacers have done without Tyrese Haliburton. â€¦ Itâ€™s not the worst-case scenario. Indiana has quickly pivoted to becoming a tanking team, once it became clear it had no chance of seriously competing for a playoff spot. â€¦ In that sense, they are a success, falling to the bottom of the Eastern Conference standings, in line for a top-four overall pick. Could be a lot worse, actually.Grade: CMiami Heat (23-21)Midseason MVP: Norman Powell (24-4-3 on 49/42/85)Offensive rating: 113.7 (20th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 112.8 (8th)Best lineup: Powell â€¢ Tyler Herro â€¢ Davion Mitchell â€¢ Andrew Wiggins â€¢ Bam Adebayo (+27 in 94 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 10-18 â€¢ Against losing teams: 13-3Comments: The Heat installed a new, almost pick-and-roll-less offense, which was all the rage as the season began, only to settle in at 20th in the NBA on that end by midseason. â€¦ They still play at the fastest pace in the league â€” by a wide margin. â€¦ Norm Powell, the Clippersâ€™ loss, is Miamiâ€™s gain. â€¦ Bam Adebayo, forever an anchor of a top-10 defense. â€¦ The Heat are 4-7 with Tyler Herro in the lineup and cannot find any sense of a rhythm as he battles a series of injuries.Grade: CMilwaukee Bucks (18-24)Midseason MVP: Giannis Antetokounmpo (29-10-6 on 65/40/65)Offensive rating: 113.0 (23rd) â€¢ Defensive rating: 116.1 (20th)Best lineup: Antetokounmpo â€¢Â Ryan Rollins â€¢ Kevin Porter Jr. â€¢ AJ Green â€¢ Myles Turner (+44 in 173 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 6-18 â€¢ Against losing teams: 12-6Comments: The Bucks are performing like a top-tier team when Giannis Antetokounmpo is on the court, outscoring opponents by 6.9 points per 100 possessions. â€¦ They are operating like a bottom-dweller when he is on the bench, getting outscored by 9.5 points per 100 possessions. â€¦ Still, Antetokounmpo insists he will not ask out of Milwaukee, leaving that discussion to the team and his agents. â€¦ Might the Bucks make one more desperation move to satiate Giannis?Â Grade: DNew York Knicks (25-18)Midseason MVP: Jalen Brunson (28-3-6 on 48/39/85)Offensive rating: 118.9 (4th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 115.9 (18th)Best lineup: Brunson â€¢ Miles McBride â€¢ Josh Hart â€¢ Mikal Bridges â€¢ Karl-Anthony Towns (+45 in 118 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 11-13 â€¢ Against losing teams: 14-5Comments: The Knicks, who entered the season as betting favorites to win the East, are now staring up at Detroit in that regard. â€¦ They also trail the Tatum-less Celtics in the standings. â€¦ They are 2-9 with the 27th-ranked net rating (-8.4) in their last 11 games. â€¦ Newsdayâ€™s sources suggested the sharks are circling Karl-Anthony Towns, though another report shot down that idea. â€¦ It is hard to imagine the Knicks shaking up their core for anyone but Antetokounmpo.Grade: COrlando Magic (23-19)Midseason MVP: Paolo Banchero (21-9-5 on 45/27/76)Offensive rating: 114.4 (18th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 113.6 (12th)Best lineup: Banchero â€¢ Jalen Suggs â€¢ Desmond Bane â€¢ Franz Wagner â€¢ Wendell Carter Jr. (+47 in 117 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 12-12 â€¢ Against losing teams: 11-7Comments: Franz Wagner and Paolo Banchero have played 16 games together; the Magic are 8-8 in those outings. â€¦ Hard to tell what Orlando is capable of, since Jalen Suggs has also had trouble staying on the court. â€¦ Anthony Blackâ€™s progress (16-4-4 on 47/36/73 shooting splits) is a revelation. â€¦ Of the 48 players who have taken 15 or more shots per game, Banchero ranks 44th in true shooting percentage (55%). â€¦ Can Orlando get back into the top 10 on defense?Grade: CPhiladelphia 76ers (23-19)Midseason MVP: Tyrese Maxey (30-4-7 on 47/40/88)Offensive rating: 114.4 (15th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 113.2 (11th)Best lineup: Maxey â€¢Â VJ Edgecombe â€¢ Paul George â€¢ Dominick Barlow â€¢ Joel Embiid (+22 in 142 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 9-14 â€¢ Against losing teams: 14-5Comments: Tyrese Maxey, what a player. â€¦ VJ Edgecombe is going to be a heck of a backcourt partner to Maxey. The 76ers are set there. â€¦ Joel Embiid since mid-December: 28-8-4 on 51/30/86 splits, and he can barely even jump. Can he stay healthy through multiple rounds of playoffs? â€¦ Paul George is also contributing as somewhat of an outsized role player. â€¦ Who wants to face these Sixers in the first round? Just imagine if they acquire another wing.Grade: BToronto Raptors (26-19)Midseason MVP: Scottie Barnes (20-8-6 on 50/32/82)Offensive rating: 114.1 (19th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 112.5 (6th)Best lineup: Barnes â€¢Â Immanuel Quickley â€¢ RJ Barrett â€¢ Brandon Ingram â€¢ Jakob Poeltl (+18 in 166 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 11-12 â€¢ Against losing teams: 15-7Comments: The Raptors own the leagueâ€™s sixth-rated defense, and their rim protector, Jakob Poeltl, has not played since Dec. 21 â€¦ You can see why Toronto might be interested in Anthony Davis. â€¦ You can see why they might want Ja Morant, too, since the Immanuel Quickley spot could also be upgraded. â€¦ But who wants the three years left on his deal after this season? â€¦ Collectively, though, we couldnâ€™t ask for much more from this team, especially Brandon Ingram.Grade: AWashington Wizards (10-32)Midseason MVP: Alex Sarr (17-7-3 on 51/35/70)Offensive rating: 109.6 (28th) â€¢ Defensive rating: 120.7 (29th)Best lineup: Sarr â€¢ Bub Carrington â€¢ Tre Johnson â€¢Â Kyshawn George â€¢Â Khris Middleton (-5 in 41 minutes)Against .500+ teams: 2-20 â€¢ Against losing teams: 8-12Comments: Is Trae Young ever going to play for this team this season? Maybe they will nurse his quad injury for as long as it takes to pull their tank into a bottom-four spot. â€¦ The Wizards are still waiting on a star to emerge from their recent string of first-round draft picks, though Alex Sarr (17-7-3 on 51/35/70 shooting splits and a league-leading 2.2 blocks per game) is a player. â€¦ Get Tre Johnson more shots than his 10 per game. â€¦ Another high-end lottery pick loading.Grade: B
author: Ben Rohrbach

title: Lakers center DeAndre Ayton shows off new look after leaving game due to eye poke: 'He looks like a pirate'
description: Deandre Ayton could be back in time for the Lakers' next game.
content_html: Los Angeles Lakers big man Deandre Ayton is temporarily adopting a new look. After leaving Tuesday's contest due to an eye poke, Ayton posted a photo on Instagram in which he's wearing a patch over his eye.On the photo, Ayton added a pirate emoji, poking fun at his appearance.From Deandreâ€™s IG: https://t.co/BVi0xIjnXgpic.twitter.com/fnXvfYnQonâ€” Dave McMenamin (@mcten) January 21, 2026He was far from the only member of the Lakers to make that comparison. After the contest, Lakers head coach JJ Redick said Ayton looked "like a pirate" after leaving the contest just before halftime.Â Ayton did not play the entire third quarter due to the injury. Before the fourth quarter was over, the Lakers announced he would miss the rest of the contest. He finished with four points and eight rebounds in roughly 15 minutes during the Lakers' 115-107 win over the Denver Nuggets.While Redick said Ayton's eye was "not in good shape" after the game, the team doesn't expect Ayton to miss time. Redick added that the center "will be fine" ahead of Thursday's game against the Los Angeles Clippers. Even if Ayton needs to miss that game, it doesn't sound like the eye injury will keep him sidelined for long.Â After spending the last two seasons with the Portland Trail Blazers, Ayton joined the Lakers on a two-year deal in the offseason. He's put up his usual numbers through 37 games with the team, averaging 13.9 points and 8.8 rebounds.
author: Chris Cwik

title: What does losing Jimmy Butler mean for the Warriors as we know them?
description: Golden State's best-laid plans have gone up in smoke. Is it finally time for a hard reset?
content_html: Adding Jimmy Butler fundamentally changed who the Warriors were last season â€” the way they played, the heights they could aspire to, their chances of playing meaningful basketball deep into springtime once again. Losing Butler on Monday to a torn right ACL â€” a devastating blow that sapped every ounce of sweetness out of Golden Stateâ€™s fourth consecutive double-digit win â€” fundamentally changes who the Warriors are this season, and threatens a devastating alteration to who they could conceivably still be in the â€œfading dynastyâ€ stage of the Stephen Curry/Draymond Green/Steve Kerr era.Letâ€™s start with the obvious: It is extremely, extremely damaging to lose a player as good as Butler, whose teams have either outright won or been demonstrably better in his minutes in every season save the one where he was trying to force his way out of Minnesota.Even at age 36, a crisp 15 years and nearly 35,000 NBA minutes into his career, Butler remains one of the leagueâ€™s best all-around players â€” a high-efficiency, low-mistake offensive connector; a versatile and disruptive defender; a high-IQ adaptor able to fit neatly into the flow when playing alongside Curry and scale up into a larger, more central role when Stephâ€™s off the floor; a consistently high-floor contributor with few peers at his position.(Grant Thomas/Yahoo Sports illutration)Butler is second on the Warriors in scoring, third in assists and rebounds, and leads them in steals and total minutes played.
